hints_html:
If p(t) is the probability density function of a continuous random variable X, then the probability that an event \(a_1 \leq X \leq a_2\) happens is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{a_1}^{a_2} p(t)\,dt.\end{aligned}\]

How can you relate the given cumulative function F(t) to the probability density function p(t)? You don’t need to calculate p(t) here if you use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
hints_latex:
How can you relate the given cumulative function \emph{F(t)} to the
probability density function \emph{p(t)}? You don't need to calculate
\emph{p(t)} here if you use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
hints_raw:
If ''p(t)'' is the probability density function of a continuous random variable ''X'', then the probability that an event <math>a_1 \leq X \leq a_2</math> happens is given by

:<math> \int_{a_1}^{a_2} p(t)\,dt. </math>
How can you relate the given cumulative function ''F(t)'' to the probability density function ''p(t)''? You don't need to calculate ''p(t)'' here if you use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
Again, let X be the continuous random variable that denotes the waiting time. Since \(F'(t)\ = p(t)\) we can use the Fundamental theorem of calculus to find the probability that the cell will divide between 3 and 6 hours:

\[\begin{aligned} p(3 \leq X \leq 6) &= \int_3^6 p(t)\,dt \\ &= F(6)-F(3) = (1-e^{-6/12}) - (1-e^{-3/12}) \\ &= e^{-1/4} - e^{-1/2} \\ &(\approx 17.2\%)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Again, let \emph{X} be the continuous random variable that denotes the
waiting time. Since $F'(t)\ = p(t)$ we can use the Fundamental theorem
of calculus to find the probability that the cell will divide between
\emph{3} and \emph{6} hours:

\begin{align*}
p(3 \leq X \leq 6) &= \int_3^6 p(t)\,dt \\
&= F(6)-F(3) = (1-e^{-6/12}) - (1-e^{-3/12}) \\
&= e^{-1/4} - e^{-1/2} \\
&(\approx 17.2\%)
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Again, let ''X'' be the continuous random variable that denotes the waiting time. Since <math> F'(t)\ = p(t)</math> we can use the Fundamental theorem of calculus to find the probability that the cell will divide between ''3'' and ''6'' hours:

:<math> \begin{align}
p(3 \leq X \leq 6) &= \int_3^6 p(t)\,dt \\
&= F(6)-F(3) = (1-e^{-6/12}) - (1-e^{-3/12}) \\
&= e^{-1/4} - e^{-1/2} \\
&(\approx 17.2\%)
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again before t hours (where t \(\geq\) 0) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\end{aligned}\]

(b) What is the probability that the cell will divide between 3 and 6 hours? (Leave your answer in terms of \(e\).)
statement_raw:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again '''before''' ''t'' hours (where ''t'' ≥ 0) is given by
:<math> F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}</math>

(b) What is the probability that the cell will divide between 3 and 6 hours? (Leave your answer in terms of <math>e</math>.)
